title: Single‐incision sling operations for urinary incontinence in women
authors: Carter, E; Johnson, EE; Still, M; Al-Assaf, AS; Bryant, A; Aluko, P; Jeffery, ST; Nambiar, A

response.output:
Is a single‑incision sling (a tiny tape placed through the vaginal wall) as effective as other sling surgeries for treating stress urinary incontinence (inability to hold urine in the bladder when pressure increases, causing leakage) in women?

Key messages  
- A single‑incision sling works about as well as retropubic slings (a tape placed through an incision near the pubic bone) and transobturator slings (a tape placed through the side of the pelvis) to cure or improve stress urinary incontinence after roughly one year, but the evidence is limited.  
- Compared with transobturator slings, single‑incision slings probably cause less pain after surgery and show similar rates of mesh exposure (visible mesh through tissue), and they may reduce urinary retention (difficulty emptying the bladder).  
- Most studies only followed women for up to 12 months and many had design weaknesses, so we need larger, longer‑term trials to understand safety and durability.

What is stress urinary incontinence and why does it matter?  
Stress urinary incontinence occurs when activities that increase pressure on the bladder—such as coughing, laughing, exercising, or lifting—cause urine to leak. It affects many women worldwide, leading to embarrassment, reduced daily activities, and costly medical visits.

What are single‑incision sling operations?  
A single‑incision sling is a minimally‑invasive surgery that uses a short synthetic (man‑made) strip of mesh placed through a tiny cut (incision) in the front (anterior) vaginal wall. The strip supports the middle part of the urethra (the tube that carries urine out of the bladder). Because only one small incision is needed, the procedure is marketed as causing less postoperative (after surgery) pain, quicker recovery, and fewer complications than older sling techniques.

What did we want to find out?  
We aimed to compare single‑incision slings with other common treatments—retropubic slings, transobturator slings, and autologous fascial slings (tissue taken from the same person)—to see how well they improve symptoms and what side‑effects they cause. We also looked for any cost‑effectiveness studies.

How did we look for evidence?  
We searched electronic databases such as PubMed, Embase, and the Cochrane Library without date or language limits. Two reviewers screened titles, abstracts, and full texts independently and resolved disagreements together. We extracted data on participants, interventions, outcomes (for example cure rate, complications), and follow‑up length. When possible, we combined results using a random‑effects meta‑analysis and assessed confidence with the GRADE approach.

What did we find?  
We identified 62 randomised trials that enrolled 8 051 women with stress‑dominant urinary incontinence. Ten trials compared single‑incision slings with retropubic slings, 51 trials compared them with transobturator slings, and one small trial (70 women) compared them with an autologous fascial sling. Sixteen trials used the TVT‑Secur sling, which has been withdrawn; we analysed those separately. No studies compared single‑incision slings with no treatment, conservative therapy, colposuspension, or laparoscopic procedures.

What are the main results?  
- Effectiveness: At 12 months, single‑incision slings gave similar cure or improvement rates as retropubic slings (low‑certainty evidence) and as transobturator slings (high‑certainty evidence).  
- Post‑operative pain: Compared with transobturator slings, single‑incision slings probably result in considerably less pain two years after surgery (moderate‑certainty evidence).  
- Mesh exposure: The chance of mesh exposure, extrusion or erosion was comparable between single‑incision and transobturator slings (high‑certainty evidence). Evidence versus retropubic slings remains very uncertain.  
- Urinary retention: Single‑incision slings likely reduce the chance of postoperative urinary retention a little compared with transobturator slings (moderate‑certainty evidence). The effect versus retropubic slings is unclear.  
- Quality of life (how someone feels and functions day to day): Women with single‑incision slings may report slightly lower quality of life at 12 months compared with transobturator slings (low‑certainty evidence).  
- Repeat surgery or sling revision: We did not have enough data to decide whether single‑incision slings increase or decrease the need for further continence surgery.  
- Other outcomes: Very limited data exist on dyspareunia (painful sex) or mesh‑related complications when single‑incision slings are compared with autologous fascial slings.

What are the limitations?  
We have little confidence in the evidence because many studies were small, participants often knew which sling they received, and the trials of different populations used varied methods. The evidence does not cover all patient groups, interventions, comparators, or outcomes of interest.

How current is the evidence?  
This review updates our previous work and includes studies published up to September 2022.
